abstract.text: An anchor that tethers entities to a scene.

inlineContent.text: Control how RealityKit places virtual objects into your scene with anchor entities.
conforms to the
protocol,
which gives it an
instance.
RealityKit places anchors based on the anchoring component’s
property. For example, you can
configure an anchor entity to rest on a horizontal surface that RealityKit detects in an AR
scene like a table or floor, and RealityKit automatically places that anchor
after it detects an appropriate horizontal plane in the real world.
The example below creates an anchor to a horizontal surface:
See
for more
information about the different types of anchors available when using Reality Composer Pro.
Add anchor entities directly to your scene’s
collection,
or anywhere else in the scene hierarchy by adding them to the
collection of another entity in your scene. Because
is a subclass of
, you can make an anchor entity
a subentity of any other entity. RealityKit might move anchor entities as the
scene updates, so the location and rotation of the anchor entity can change
relative to its container entity, even if your code never modifies its
property.
Some anchor entities might not show up in your scene at all if RealityKit
fails to detect an appropriate place for them. For example, an anchor entity
with an
target doesn’t show up in the scene until RealityKit detects
the specified image in the real world.
You can have multiple anchors in a RealityKit scene. For example, one anchor
can place a toy car on a horizontal surface, like a table, and another
can tie an informative text bubble to an image in the same scene.
By default, physics bodies and colliders affect only entities that share
the same anchor.
An entity and its descendants can participate in the physics simulation at the
root of your scene by setting its
to

abstract.text: Simulate and render 3D content for use in your augmented reality apps.
An anchor that tethers entities to a scene.
The identifier of the AR anchor with which the anchor entity is
associated, or
if it isn’t currently anchored.
The component that describes how the virtual content is anchored to the
real world.
Creates a new anchor entity.
Creates an anchor entity targeting a particular kind of anchor.
Creates an anchor entity that uses an existing AR anchor.
Creates an anchor entity that targets a plane with the given
characteristics.
Creates an anchor entity using the information about a real-world
surface discovered using a ray-cast query.
Creates an anchor entity with a target fixed at the given position in
the scene.
Creates an anchor entity with a target fixed at the given position in
the scene.
Changes the entity’s anchoring, preserving either the world transform or
the local transform.
A component that anchors virtual content to a real world target.
Opts out the entity and its descendants from having their own physics space.
Defines the kinds of real world objects to which an anchor entity can be tethered.
Decides how the
tracks its target anchor.
Specifies the physics simulation spece that the entity and its descendants are in.
The real world anchor target to attach the entity to.
An element of a RealityKit scene to which you attach components that provide
appearance and behavior characteristics for the entity.
The child entities that the entity manages.
The transform of an entity relative to its parent.
A type on which events can be published and subscribed.
An interface that enables anchoring of virtual content to a real-world
object in an AR scene.
An interface that provides access to a parent entity and child entities.
An interface that enables an entity to be synchronized between processes and
networked applications.
An interface that enables manipulating the scale, rotation, and translation
of an entity.
A 3D coordinate space that exists within a RealityKit hierarchy.
The collection of anchors contained in the scene.
Create procedurally generated shape primitives to your Reality Composer scene.

abstract.text: Create a more interactive user experience by choosing exactly where to anchor Reality
Composer scenes.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A class of types whose instances hold the value of an entity with stable identity.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
